subject: Physics
expanded_description: Comprehensive study of magnetic forces on moving charges, including the Lorentz force law, motion in magnetic fields, applications in particle accelerators and mass spectrometers, and the fundamental differences between electric and magnetic forces.
learning_objectives: Apply the Lorentz force law to calculate magnetic forces on moving charges
Predict charged particle trajectories in uniform magnetic fields
Analyze motion in crossed electric and magnetic fields
Solve problems involving magnetic force applications
Distinguish between electric and magnetic force characteristics
Apply right-hand rules for force direction determination

core_concept.principle: Magnetic force on moving charge: $\vec{F}_B = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$, Magnitude: $F_B = |q|vB\sin\theta$, Direction: perpendicular to both velocity and field, Right-hand rule for positive charges, left-hand for negative. Work done: $W = \vec{F}_B \cdot d\vec{l} = 0$ (no work, kinetic energy constant).
core_concept.explanation: Magnetic forces act only on moving charges, are perpendicular to both velocity and field directions, and change direction but not speed of charged particles, resulting in curved trajectories.

sections.section_title: 1. Lorentz Force Law and Fundamental Principles
sections.introduction: Introduction to magnetic force on moving charges using the Lorentz force law, analysis of force direction and magnitude, and comparison with electric forces.

key_concept.definition: Lorentz force fundamentals: $\vec{F} = q\vec{E} + q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$, Magnetic component $\vec{F}_B = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$, Magnitude $F_B = |q|vB\sin\theta$, Maximum force when v⟂B, Zero force when v∥B, Direction perpendicular to plane containing v and B, Right-hand rule: fingers v to B, thumb F for q>0, Work principle: magnetic forces do no work, speed constant.
key_concept.context: The magnetic force acts as a deflecting force that changes direction but not speed of charged particles, with magnitude depending on charge, speed, field strength, and their relative orientation.

image.caption: Magnetic force dependence on velocity-field angle

classifications.value: Classification based on relative orientation of velocity and magnetic field
classifications.behavior: Different configurations produce characteristic motions: perpendicular velocity gives circular motion; parallel velocity gives straight motion; arbitrary angle gives helical motion; multiple charges experience different forces based on sign and speed; time-varying fields cause acceleration; crossed fields can produce straight motion when balanced

examples.explanation: When charged particle velocity is perpendicular to uniform magnetic field, magnetic force provides centripetal acceleration causing circular motion with constant speed but changing direction
For velocity at angle θ to magnetic field, motion decomposes into circular motion from perpendicular component and uniform motion from parallel component, resulting in helical trajectory

classifications.note: Magnetic force is always perpendicular to velocity, so it changes direction but not speed. The right-hand rule gives force direction for positive charges; reverse for negative charges. Maximum force occurs when velocity perpendicular to field. Zero force when velocity parallel to field. Magnetic forces do no work since F⟂v. The cross product ensures force is perpendicular to both v and B.

principles.statement: The magnetic force on a moving charge follows specific directional and magnitude rules: Direction: Given by the vector cross product $\vec{F}_B = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$, which is always perpendicular to both velocity and magnetic field vectors. For positive charges, use right-hand rule: point fingers in direction of $\vec{v}$, curl toward $\vec{B}$, thumb gives $\vec{F}_B$ direction. For negative charges, force is opposite. Magnitude: $F_B = |q|vB\sin\theta$, where θ is angle between velocity and field vectors. Key implications: (1) Maximum force when θ = 90° (v⟂B), (2) Zero force when θ = 0° or 180° (v∥B), (3) Force increases linearly with charge, speed, and field strength, (4) Force direction reverses if either charge sign or velocity direction reverses, (5) Magnetic forces can change direction but not speed of particles (do no work). This directional relationship explains why charged particles curve in magnetic fields and why certain configurations produce circular or helical paths.
principles.application: Determine force direction using right-hand rules. Calculate force magnitude for various orientations. Predict particle trajectories in magnetic fields. Design magnetic deflection systems. Analyze force on charged particle beams. Solve problems involving multiple charges with different velocities.
principles.example: Proton moving east in northward magnetic field: right-hand rule gives upward force. Electron same conditions: force downward (negative charge)
principles.analogy: Like a string providing centripetal force for circular motion - always perpendicular to velocity, changing direction but not speed

image.caption: Right-hand rule and force magnitude dependence

worked_examples.title: Basic Magnetic Force Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A proton (q=+1.6×10⁻¹⁹ C) moves at 2×10⁶ m/s through 0.5 T magnetic field. Calculate magnetic force when: (a) v⟂B, (b) v at 30° to B, (c) v∥B.

step_by_step.explanation: Use right-hand rule for specific directions; force perpendicular to plane containing v and B

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 1.6×10⁻¹³ N when v⟂B, (b) 8×10⁻¹⁴ N at 30°, (c) 0 N when v∥B. Force direction perpendicular to v-B plane.

worked_examples.title: Force Direction Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Determine magnetic force direction for: (a) Proton moving right in field into page, (b) Electron moving up in field right, (c) Alpha particle (q=+2e) moving out of page in field down.

step_by_step.explanation: Right-hand rule: v right, B into page → F up
Left-hand rule or reverse right-hand: v up, B right → F into page
Right-hand rule: v out of page, B down → F right
Use cross product: î×(-k̂)=ĵ, ĵ×î=-k̂, k̂×(-ĵ)=î

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Force upward, (b) Force into page, (c) Force to right. Directions consistent with cross product and charge signs.

sections.section_title: 2. Charged Particle Motion in Magnetic Fields
sections.introduction: Analysis of charged particle trajectories in magnetic fields, including circular motion, helical paths, and applications in particle control and measurement devices.

key_concept.definition: Particle motion analysis: Circular motion when v⟂B, Radius $r = \frac{mv}{|q|B}$, Period $T = \frac{2\pi m}{|q|B}$ (independent of v), Frequency $f = \frac{|q|B}{2\pi m}$, Helical motion when v at angle, Pitch $p = v_{parallel}T$, Combined E and B fields, Velocity selector $v = E/B$, Mass spectrometer principles.
key_concept.context: Magnetic fields cause charged particles to follow curved paths with characteristics determined by particle properties and field strength, enabling particle control and measurement.

image.alt: Charged particle motion in magnetic fields
image.caption: Circular and helical trajectories in uniform fields

classifications.value: Classification based on initial conditions and field configuration
characteristics: Adiabatic motion in slowly varying B
classifications.behavior: Different trajectories arise from specific conditions: uniform B with v⟂B gives circles; v with parallel component gives helices; non-uniform B causes drift; resonant frequencies enable acceleration; crossed fields produce straight motion when balanced; slowly varying fields conserve magnetic moment

examples.explanation: Uniform magnetic field provides centripetal force: qvB = mv²/r, giving radius r = mv/(qB), with period T = 2πr/v = 2πm/(qB) independent of speed

When velocity has components both perpendicular and parallel to B, circular motion from perpendicular component combines with uniform motion from parallel component, producing helical path around field lines

classifications.note: The cyclotron radius r = mv/(qB) shows heavier or faster particles curve less, while stronger fields or higher charge cause tighter curvature. The period T = 2πm/(qB) is speed-independent, crucial for cyclotrons. Helical motion occurs when velocity isn't purely perpendicular. In crossed E and B fields, particles can move undeflected when v = E/B. Magnetic mirrors use field gradients to reflect particles.

principles.statement: Charged particles executing circular motion in magnetic fields exhibit cyclotron motion with radius $r = \frac{mv}{|q|B}$ and period $T = \frac{2\pi m}{|q|B}$. Key features: (1) Radius proportional to momentum (mv), (2) Period independent of speed and radius - all particles with same m/q ratio have same period regardless of energy, (3) Frequency $f = \frac{|q|B}{2\pi m}$ depends only on m/q ratio and B field, (4) Kinetic energy $K = \frac{(qBr)^2}{2m}$ relates to measurable radius. These relationships enable mass spectrometry: particles with different m/q ratios follow different radii in same B field, allowing separation and identification. In cyclotrons, the constant period allows resonant acceleration using fixed-frequency electric fields. The radius-momentum relationship is used in particle physics to identify particles from their curved tracks in magnetic fields. This principle forms the basis for numerous analytical instruments and accelerator technologies.
principles.application: Calculate particle trajectories in magnetic fields. Design mass spectrometers for chemical analysis. Understand cyclotron accelerator operation. Determine particle properties from curved tracks. Analyze charged particle beams. Solve problems involving particle separation.
principles.example: Mass spectrometer: ions accelerated through voltage V, then curved in magnetic field, radius r = √(2mV)/(qB) allows mass determination
principles.analogy: Like cars on a racetrack - faster cars need wider turns (larger radius), but all cars take same time per lap if track scaled proportionally

image.caption: Radius and period relationships for circular motion

worked_examples.title: Electron in Magnetic Field
worked_examples.problem: An electron (m=9.11×10⁻³¹ kg, q=-1.6×10⁻¹⁹ C) moves at 2×10⁶ m/s perpendicular to 0.01 T magnetic field. Find: (a) Force magnitude, (b) Radius of path, (c) Period of motion, (d) Kinetic energy.

step_by_step.explanation: Electron (negative charge) circles opposite direction to right-hand rule

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Force: 3.2×10⁻¹⁵ N, (b) Radius: 1.14 mm, (c) Period: 3.58 ns, (d) Energy: 11.4 eV. Electron circles clockwise (opposite proton direction).

worked_examples.title: Mass Spectrometer Analysis
worked_examples.problem: In a mass spectrometer, singly charged ions (q=+e) are accelerated through 1000 V, then enter 0.2 T magnetic field perpendicularly. Calculate path radii for: (a) H⁺ (m=1.67×10⁻²⁷ kg), (b) D⁺ (m=3.34×10⁻²⁷ kg), (c) O⁺ (m=2.66×10⁻²⁶ kg).

step_by_step.explanation: r = mv/(qB) = m√(2qV/m)/(qB) = √(2mV)/(qB²) but careful: r = √(2mV/q)/B

worked_examples.final_answer: Path radii: (a) H⁺: 7.22 cm, (b) D⁺: 10.2 cm, (c) O⁺: 28.9 cm. Different masses clearly separated by magnetic field.

sections.introduction: Practical applications of magnetic forces on moving charges, including velocity selectors, mass spectrometers, and analysis of motion in combined electric and magnetic fields.

key_concept.definition: Applications: Velocity selector $v = E/B$ when F_E = F_B, Mass spectrometer $r = \frac{mv}{qB} = \frac{\sqrt{2mqV}}{qB}$, Cyclotron $f = \frac{qB}{2\pi m}$, Hall effect $V_H = \frac{IB}{nqt}$, Magnetic confinement, Particle beams, Cathode ray tubes, Combined fields: $\vec{F} = q\vec{E} + q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$, E×B drift, Magnetic mirrors.
key_concept.context: Magnetic forces enable precise control of charged particles for analytical instruments, accelerators, and various technologies, with combined electric and magnetic fields producing specialized motion patterns.

image.caption: Practical devices using magnetic forces on charges

classifications.value: Classification based on device function and operating principle
classifications.behavior: Different applications exploit specific magnetic force properties: velocity selectors use balanced E and B fields; mass spectrometers use mass-dependent curvature; cyclotrons use constant period; beam optics use field gradients; magnetic mirrors use increasing field strength; Hall sensors use transverse voltage development

examples.explanation: Crossed electric and magnetic fields allow only particles with specific velocity v = E/B to pass undeflected, since electric force qE balances magnetic force qvB at this velocity
Charged particles spiral outward in magnetic field while being accelerated by synchronized electric field at constant cyclotron frequency, gaining energy with each crossing

classifications.note: Velocity selectors work because F_E = qE (independent of v) while F_B = qvB (proportional to v). Mass spectrometers combine electric acceleration with magnetic deflection. Cyclotrons exploit the speed-independent period of circular motion. Hall effect measures carrier density and type. Magnetic confinement uses curved field lines to contain plasmas. E×B drift causes perpendicular motion in crossed fields.

principles.principle: Velocity Selector and Crossed Field Dynamics
principles.statement: When electric and magnetic fields are perpendicular to each other and both perpendicular to particle velocity ($\vec{E} \perp \vec{B} \perp \vec{v}$), remarkable motion patterns occur: Velocity Selector: For particles with specific velocity $v = E/B$, electric force $qE$ exactly balances magnetic force $qvB$, resulting in straight-line motion undeflected. Particles with $v < E/B$ curve toward E direction, those with $v > E/B$ curve opposite. E×B Drift: When forces don't balance, particles undergo complex motion combining oscillation with steady drift velocity $\vec{v}_d = \frac{\vec{E} \times \vec{B}}{B^2}$ perpendicular to both fields. This drift is independent of charge sign, mass, and velocity. Crossed Field Applications: (1) Velocity selectors for producing monoenergetic particle beams, (2) Mass spectrometers for separating ions by mass, (3) Thomson's e/m experiment for measuring charge-to-mass ratio, (4) Plasma confinement in fusion devices, (5) Hall effect measurements in semiconductors. Understanding crossed field dynamics is essential for designing particle beam systems and analytical instruments.
principles.application: Design velocity selectors for specific energy ranges. Analyze particle motion in crossed fields. Understand mass spectrometer operation. Calculate drift velocities in plasma devices. Design Hall effect sensors. Solve problems involving balanced electric and magnetic forces.
principles.example: Velocity selector with E=1000 V/m, B=0.01 T passes particles with v=100,000 m/s. Faster particles curve one way, slower particles the other
principles.analogy: Like a river crossing - if swimming speed matches current, you go straight across; if slower, you drift downstream; if faster, you can angle upstream

image.caption: Particle motion in perpendicular E and B fields

worked_examples.title: Velocity Selector Design
worked_examples.problem: Design a velocity selector to pass 1000 eV protons. Available: magnetic field up to 0.1 T, electric field up to 10⁴ V/m. Find: (a) Required E and B, (b) Selectable velocity, (c) What happens to 500 eV and 2000 eV protons?

step_by_step.explanation: Use B=0.1 T maximum, then E = (4.38×10⁵)(0.1) = 4.38×10⁴ V/m, but limited to 10⁴ V/m. So use E=10⁴ V/m maximum, then B = E/v = 10⁴/(4.38×10⁵) = 0.0228 T
v = 3.10×10⁵ m/s, v < E/B so curve toward E direction
v = 6.19×10⁵ m/s, v > E/B so curve opposite E direction

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Use E=10⁴ V/m, B=0.0228 T, (b) Selects v=4.38×10⁵ m/s (1000 eV protons), (c) 500 eV protons curve toward E, 2000 eV protons curve away from E.

image.caption: Field selection for specific particle energy

worked_examples.title: Hall Effect Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A copper strip 1 mm thick, 2 cm wide carries 10 A current in 0.5 T magnetic field perpendicular to strip. Copper has 8.5×10²⁸ electrons/m³. Find Hall voltage and which side is positive.

step_by_step.explanation: V_H = IB/(nqt) where t is thickness perpendicular to B
Electrons (negative) deflect by F=qv×B, so accumulate on one side, making opposite side positive
Conventional current right, B into page → electrons experience force down, so bottom negative, top positive
Very small voltage (0.37 μV) shows why semiconductors (lower n) used for Hall sensors

worked_examples.final_answer: Hall voltage = 0.37 μV, with top side positive. Small voltage due to high electron density in copper.

image.caption: Transverse voltage development in magnetic field

common_misconceptions: Thinking magnetic forces can increase particle speed
Believing magnetic fields affect stationary charges
Confusing force direction for positive vs negative charges
Thinking all charged particles curve the same way
Believing magnetic forces can do work
Confusing electric and magnetic force properties
real_world_applications: Cathode ray tubes and old TVs
summary: Magnetic forces on moving charges follow $\vec{F}_B = q\vec{v} × \vec{B}$, always perpendicular to both velocity and field. This force changes direction but not speed, causing curved trajectories. In uniform B with v⟂B, circular motion occurs with radius r=mv/(qB) and period T=2πm/(qB). With velocity components both parallel and perpendicular to B, helical motion results. Crossed electric and magnetic fields enable velocity selection when v=E/B. Applications include mass spectrometers (separating ions by mass), cyclotrons (resonant acceleration), velocity selectors (producing monoenergetic beams), and Hall effect devices (measuring carrier properties). Magnetic forces enable precise control of charged particles for numerous scientific, medical, and technological applications.
